subject: RE: [junit] catching Throwables (Was:  Should JUnit determine if assert*/fail is called in testFoo?)
msgSnippet: ... I don t agree.  You should catch ( ). ... I don t! ... You could log it, so that you know a given problem has occurred,
messageBody:
> same. Also, you might want to make that "catch (Throwable t)"

I don't agree. You should catch (<exceptions declared in throw
clause>).

> On this point, does anybody here catches Throwables inside his code?

I don't!

> I do. Even if not *supposed* to. Because when I "try"
> something, I want nothing to crap out except possibly that
> thing, and I want to know about it.

You could log it, so that you know a given problem has occurred, then
you could look at the resons that caused the error to fix the bug. But
you should then let the error filter up the chain to be handled by the
correct error handler, or even halt the JVM process if it comes to that.

> For exemple, if there is a classpath problem preventing me to
> do X(), I want to catch the NoClassDefFoundError, log the
> error, and invoke my recovery strategy (msg to user,
> alternate method, etc..), Not let the error go all the way to
> the top and possibly stop some important top-level task (or
> worse the entire jvm process).

In this example, I would not catch Throwable, then. I would catch
NoClassDefFoundError.

The only place where I /may/ catch Throwable explicitly, is at the very
top of the call stack (main(), or some run() method), where I log the
error before gracefully shutting down, or start some other recovery
strategy. However, this should only be done when a recovery strategy is
available. What do you do in the case of an OutOfMemoryError? (There
are several solutions to this problem, but I won't mention them here.)

Manuel Amago.
